It is a good conductor of electricity

1.q_string: Why is KCl used in a salt bridge?

The resistance of \(0.01 \mathrm{~N}\) solution of an electrolyte is \(210 \Omega\) at \(298 \mathrm{~K}\) with a cell constant of \(0.88 \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}\). Calculate the conductivity and equivalent conductivity of the solution.

Consider the cell:

\(\mathrm{Cd}(\mathrm{s})\left|\mathrm{Cd}^{2+}(1.0 \mathrm{M}) \| \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}(0.1 \mathrm{M})\right| \mathrm{Cu}(\mathrm{s})\)

If we wish to make a cell with a more positive voltage using the same substance, we should:

For the given cell;

\(C u(s)\left|C u^{2+}\left(C_{1} M\right) \| C u^{2+}\left(C_{2} M\right)\right| C u(s)\) change in Gibbs energy \((\Delta G)\) is negative, if:

q_option: The molar conductance decreases, but equivalent conductance increases upon dilution.
The molar conductance increases, while equivalent conductance decreases upon dilution.
1.q_string: Which of the following statements regarding dilution of an electrolytic solution is correct?
How many hours does it take to reduce 3 moles of \(\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}\) to \(\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}\) with \(2.0 \mathrm{~A}\) current intensity?

The mass of copper that will be deposited at cathode in electrolysis of \(0.2 \mathrm{M}\) solution of copper sulphate when a quantity of electricity equal to hat required to liberate

2.24L of hydrogen from \(0.1 \mathrm{M}\) aqueous \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\) is passed (atomic mass of \(\mathrm{C}=63.5\) ) will be:

A solution containing one mole per litre each of \(\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}, \mathrm{AgNO}_{3}, \mathrm{Hg}_{2}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}\) and \(\mathrm{Mg}\left(\mathrm{NO}_{3}\right)_{2}\) is being electrolysed by using inert electrodes. The values of standard electrode potentials in volt (reduction potentials) are:

\(\mathrm{Ag} / \mathrm{Ag}^{+}=0.80, \quad 2 \mathrm{Hg} / \mathrm{Hg}_{2}^{2+}=0.79 \)

\(\mathrm{Cu} / \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}=+0.34 \text { and } \mathrm{Mg} / \mathrm{Mg}^{2+}=-2.37\)

With increasing voltage, the sequence of deposition of metals on the cathode will be?

q_option: Positive electrode is called cathode and negative electrode is called anode
Oxidation takes place at anode and reduction takes place at cathode
Spontaneous redox reaction takes place in electrolytic cell
Current flows from anode to cathode in the inside of the cell
1.q_string: In an electrolytic cell, which of the following statements is not true?

q_option: The positive and negative ions will be move towards anode
The positive ions will start moving towards the anode and while negative ions will stop moving
The negative ions will continue to move towards and while positive ions will stop moving
The positive and negative ions will start moving random
1.q_string: When electric current is passed through a cell having an electrolyte, the cations move towards the cathode and the anions towards the anode. If cathode is pulled out of the solution, then:

Four moles of electrons were transferred from anode to cathode in an experiment on electrolysis of water. The total volume. of the two gases (dry and at STP) produced will be approximately: (in litres)

The approximate time duration in hours to electroplate \(30 g\) of calcium from molten calcium chloride using a current of \(5 a m p\) is :

[Atomic mass of \(C a=40\) ]

What will be \(\Delta H\) for the reaction;

\(A g(s)+\frac{1}{2} H_{2} \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(s) \rightarrow A g C l(s)+H g(l)\) at \(25^{\circ} c\), if this reaction can be conducted in a cell for which the emf \(=0.0455\) volt at this temperature with temperature coefficient \(3.389 \times 10^{-4}\) voltdeg \(^{-1}\) ?

Consider the following half-cell reactions and associated standard halfcell potentials and determine the maximum voltage that can be obtained by combination resulting in spontaneous processes:

\(A u B r_{4}^{-}(a q)+3 e^{-} \rightarrow A u(s)+4 B r^{-}(a q) ; E^{\circ}=-0.86 V \)

\(E u^{3+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow E u^{2+}(a q) ; E^{\circ}=-0.43 V\)

\(S n^{2+}(a q)+2 e^{-} \rightarrow S n(s) ; E^{\circ}=-0.14 V \)

\(I O^{-}(a q)+H_{2} O(l)+2 e^{-} \rightarrow I^{-}(\mathrm{aq})+2 O H^{-}(\mathrm{aq}) ; E^{\circ}=+0.49 V\)

q_option: Electrode of half-cell potential \(-0.44 \mathrm{~V}\) will act as anode
Electrode of half-cell potential \(-0.44 \mathrm{~V}\) will act as cathode
Electrode of half-cell potential \(0.799 \mathrm{~V}\) will act as anode
Electrode of half-cell potential \(-0.44 \mathrm{~V}\) will act as a positive terminal
1.q_string: Two half-cells have potentials \(-0.44\) and \(0.799\) volt respectively. These two are coupled to make a galvanic cell. Which of the following will be true?
Which one of the following species has maximum conductance in their aqueous solutions?

Which of the following metals form a protective layer of its oxide on reaction with atmospheric oxygen?
Which of the following solutions is used as an anti-rusting solution?
Corrosion of iron may be prevented by:

A current of \(\mathrm{i}\) ampere was passed for \(\mathrm{t}\) sec, through three calls \(P, Q\) and \(T\) connected in series. These contain respectively silver nitrate, mercuric nitrate, and mercurous nitrate. At the cathode of the cell \(P, 0.216 g\) of \(A g\) was deposited. The weights of mercury deposited in the cathode of \(Q\) and R respectively are: (at wt. of \(H g=200.59\) )

q_option: The reaction occurs only once and after use it can be recharged  and reused again
Electrode reactions can be reversed by an external energy source and can be used again and again
The reaction is reversed periodically and after use over a period of time and so can be reused again
The reaction occurs only once and after use over a period of time battery becomes dead and cannot be reused again
1.q_string: In the primary batteries
A secondary cell after use  can be ________ by passing current through it in the ________ so that it can be used again.
Fuel cells are ________ that are designed to convert the energy of combustion of fuels like hydrogen, methane, methanol, etc. directly into_________.

The below reaction is the gold-plating process reaction.

\(\mathrm{Au}^{3+}(\mathrm{aq})+3 \mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})\)

If \(0.600 \mathrm{~g}\) of \(\mathrm{Au}\) is plated onto a metal, how many coulombs are used?
